respStmt.name: Walters Art Museum curatorial staff and researchers since 1934

availability.p: Licensed for use under Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported Access Rights, http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/3.0/legalcode. It is requested that copies of any published articles based on the information in this data set be sent to the curator of manuscripts, The Walters Art Museum, 600 North Charles Street, Baltimore MD 21201.

notesStmt.note: This finely illuminated and iconographically rich book of hours was made in England at the end of the thirteenth century. The manuscript is incomplete and misbound. Its main artist can also be found at work in a Bible (Oxford, Bodleian Library Ms. Auct. D.3.2) and a psalter (Cambridge, Trinity College Cambridge Ms. O.4.16). The manuscript contains a number of unusual texts, including the Hours of Jesus Crucified and the Office of St. Catherine. The patron of the manuscript is not clear; a woman is depicted as praying in many of the initials, but rubrics in the Office of the Dead mention "freres" (brothers). The imagery is inventive, and the Hours of Christ Crucified are graced with images depicting the funeral of Reynard the Fox in its margins. In the absence of a calendar, it is not possible to locate the origin of the manuscript precisely.

msContents.textLang: The primary language in this manuscript is Latin. The secondary language of this manuscript is French, Old (842-ca.1400).

msItem.title: Book of hours
msItem.note: The original sequence of the parts of this manuscript cannot be reconstructed with certainty. The Abbreviated Hours were followed by the Hours of the Holy Spirit, the Seven Penitential Psalms, the litany and collects, the Fifteen Gradual Psalms, the Office of the Dead, and the Hours of Jesus Crucified. Whether the Prayers to the Crucified Christ, which were followed by the lections in the life of St. Catharine, came before or after this sequence is an unanswered question.

msItem.title: Hours of Jesus Crucified
msItem.rubric: Si commence les hures de Iesu crucifie les queles si hume die chescun iur e pense de sa passiun ke il suffri a cheun hure il ne murra mie de male mort
msItem.incipit: Gracias tibi ago domine Iesu Chisti cuius gratia (fol. 73v)
msItem.note: Text has been scrambled; correct order as follows: fols. 73v-84v, 2r-3v

msItem.title: Prayers to the Crucified Christ
msItem.rubric: Ci commence le preface avant remembre
msItem.incipit: In nomine domini omne genuflectatur celestium

msItem.title: Lections in the life of St. Catharine, canonical hours in her honor, and miscellaneous prayers
msItem.rubric: De Seint Katerine a vespres les psaumes feriale

msItem.title: Hours of the Virgin
msItem.note: Incomplete; text has been scrambled; correct order as follows: fols. 87r-90v, 92r-93v, 86r-v, 16r-v, 91r-v

msItem.title: Hours of the Holy Spirit
msItem.rubric: Ci commencent les Hures del Seint Espirit
msItem.note: Incomplete; text has been scrambled; correct order as follows: fols. 21v-26v, 85r-v, 35r-v, 41r-43r

msItem.title: Seven Penitential Psalms
msItem.note: Text has been scrambled; correct order as follows: fols. 43r-48v, 40r-v, 27r-v

msItem.title: Litany and collects
msItem.note: Franciscan adaptation of the Roman litany

msItem.title: Fifteen Gradual Psalms
msItem.rubric: Ci commencent les Quinze Psaumes Penitenciales
msItem.note: Text has been scrambled; correct order as follows: fols. 39r-v, 31r-34v, 49r-51r

msItem.title: Office of the Dead
msItem.rubric: Ci commence le Office pur les Morz
msItem.incipit: Legem [sic] cui omnia vivunt, Venite adoremus

supportDesc.foliation: Nineteenth-century pen foliation in upper right corners of rectos (followed here); second flyleaf foliated as fol. 1, with foliation consequently ending at fol. 105; twentieth-century foliation in pencil in lower left corners of rectos

collation.p: Undetermined Occasionally found on versos of the last folios of quires in the bottom right margins Binding too tight to reconstruct the original arrangement of quires

binding.p: Early twentieth-century worn red velvet over pasteboard

history.provenance: Created in England, ca. 1300, for an unknown patron
history.acquisition: Walters Art Museum, 1931, by Henry Walters' bequest
